introduction.p: In this activity, we will explore how to transform the graph of a function f by making changes to its formula in the following ways: f(x) + k and f(x + h). By the end of this activity, you will be able to:

li.p: Recognize the geometric effect of transforming f(x) to f(x) + k and f(x + h).
Write the formula for a basic function which has been changed by these transformations.
Sketch the graph of a basic function which has been changed by these transformations.

subsection.title: Prep Activity
subsection.p: In preparation for this activity, we should revisit function evaluation with an eye toward describing changes to the input or the output.
Each of the following problems involves something you have already learned. These are skills we will need in the rest of this activity.

statement.p: Given the function f(x) = x^2 + x, write a formula for each expression below.
Given the function g(t) = -3t + 7, write a formula for each expression below.

subsection.p:
For any function y = f(x), remember that x-values are inputs, and y-values are outputs. If we change this equation to
y = f(x)+10
then we are really just adding the number 10 to all of the outputs for the original function f.
In the next exercise, you will describe changes to either the input or the output of a function.

statement.p: For each equation below, give a description of what we are changing (e.g. adding 10 to the outputs).

li.p: The equation y = f(x+4) adds 4 to the input of the function f.
The equation y = f(x)-2 subtracts 2 from the input of the function f.
The equation y = 5f(x) multiplies the output of the function f by 5.
The equation y = f(9x) multiplies the input of the function f by 9.

subsection.p: Lastly, you will write equations which match verbal descriptions of changes to the input and/or output.

statement.p: Beginning with the function y = g(t), write an equation which matches each description.

p.q: We subtracted 5 from the input and added 4 to the output.
We doubled the input and then subtracted 1 from the output.

subsection.title: The Swimmer
subsection.p: In this section, we will see the effects of changing the input or the output of a function, particularly as relates to the graph. We will follow a single story that will lead us through most of the main points of this section.

statement.p: In preparation for the swimming competition, a swimmer jumped off a diving board into a swimming pool below. Below is a graph of her height above the water as a function of time.
You can see some basic information from the graph:

li.p: How high was the diving board?
When did the swimmer reach the water?
What was her maximum height above the water?
The diving board was 3 feet high, as this is the swimmer's height above the water at t = 0 seconds.
The swimmer reached the water at approximately 1.1 seconds, according to the graph.
Her maximum height above the water was approximately 6.5 feet, according to the graph.

subsection.p: After that dive, the swimmer decided to try out the high-dive board, which is 7 feet higher than the first board. See the next exercise.

subsection.p:
Now more information about that first dive: The formula for the swimmer's height above the water after diving off the regular board is given by:
h = f(t) = -16t^2+15t+3
(You are not expected to know how this formula was made.)
Confirm that this formula really works by graphing it on your calculator.
In the next exercise, you will change this formula so it represents the swimmer's height when she used the high-dive board.

Jumping off the regular diving board, the swimmer's heigh above water is modeled by the function:

When the swimmer moves up and jumps off the high-dive board, which is 7 feet higher up, this makes the height function:

Use the formula given to write the formula for f(t) + 7, which represents increasing the output by 7.

li.p:
For the Mega high-dive, the graph of the swimmer's height function would go up by 25 feet, and the formula would be:

li.p: At the competition, the swimmer missed the starting whistle and jumped 2 seconds late. Click and drag the starting point to move the graph to match this new situation.
Jumping late is a change in the:
Which equation below makes sense for this change?
h = f(t + 2) or h = f(t - 2)

If you simplify each of these formulas, the results are:
f(t+2) = -16(t+2)^2 + 15(t+2) + 3
and
f(t-2) = -16(t-2)^2 + 15(t-2) + 3
Graph these two functions on your calculator. Which one matches the graph you made above?
Starting late is a change in the input, which is time.

The formula that moves the graph of h = f(t) to the right by 2 seconds is:
h = f(t - 2)

subsection.p: It may have surprised you to see that shifting the graph to the right corresponded to subtracting a number from the input. To make sense of this, consider one of the other swimmers in the competition who jumped when the whistle sounded. Their height function would be given by h = f(t).

If we wanted to find our swimmer's height at, say, 3 seconds after the whistle sounded, it would be the same height as this other swimmer had at only 1 second after the whistle everything for our swimmer happened 2 seconds late. In other words, to find our swimmer's height after t seconds, this is the same as the other swimmer had 2 seconds before. So for our swimmer, her height is given by:
h = f(t - 2)
The next two exercises will complete our story about the swimmer. In them, you will write formulas for her height given different diving situations.

statement.p:
Recall that the swimmer's height above the water, after jumping off the regular diving board, was given by:
h = f(t) = -16t^2 + 15t + 3

Suppose the swimmer jumped off the high-dive board, which is 7 feet higher than the regular board, but she did so 3 seconds after the timer started. Alter the formula for f(t) in order to write the formula for her height above the water in this situation.

solution.p:
This new situation corresponds to shifting the graph of h = f(t) to the right by 3 seconds and up by 7 feet, so the formula is:
h \amp= f(t - 3) + 7 \amp= \left(-16(t-3)^2 + 15(t-3) + 3\right) + 7 \amp= -16(t-3)^2 + 15(t-3) + 10

statement.p:
Recall that the swimmer's height above the water, after jumping off the regular diving board, was given by:
h = f(t) = -16t^2 + 15t + 3

Suppose on a particular dive, her height above the water was given by the formula:
h = 1 + 15(t+1) - 16(t+1)^2

li.p: Did she jump late or early?
She jumped 1 second
Did she jump off the high-dive board (7 feet higher than normal), the Mega high-dive board (25 feet higher than normal), or the Nano board (2 feet lower than normal)?
She jumped off the
Because we have added 1 to the input, this corresponds to a leftward shift of the graph by 1 second. Therefore, she jumped 1 second early.

Notice that our formula
h = 1 + 15(t+1) - 16(t+1)^2
could be written as:
h = \left(-16(t+1)^2 + 15(t+1) + 3\right) - 2
This shows that we have really subtracted 2 from the output of our original function f(t), so she has jumped off the Nano board.

subsection.title: Seeing the shifts
subsection.p:
Now we will see the effect of making a change to the output of a function by manipulating its formula. You will be able to describe what happens to the graph of a function after it has been changed from:
y = f(x) \text{to} y = f(x) + k

subsection.p: Finally, we will see an application of using vertical and horizontal shifts to quickly perform a familiar task: Finding the equation of a line

statement.p:
The linear function
f(x) = 4x
will graph as a line with slope 4, passing through the origin (0,0).
Now, using translations, it would be easy to write the equations of similar lines. For example:
The line with slope 4, passing through the point (7,15), may be thought of as the result of shifting f(x) to the right by 7 units, and up by 15 units.
[In this case, we are focusing our attention on moving the old point (0,0) to the new point (7,15).]
What would be the equation of this new line?

hint.p: Since f(x) has the point (0,0), think about shifting that point to (7,15). Remember that adding to the input will move the graph to the left, and subtracting from the input will move the graph to the right.

solution.p:
Without doing any simplification to the formula, the line would be:
y \amp= f(x-7) + 15 \amp= 4(x-7) + 15

statement.p:
The line with slope 11, passing through the origin (0,0), has the equation:

Using translations, write the equation for the line with slope 11, passing through the point (,-).

solution.p: Think of moving the point (0,0) to the point (,-).
We would shift the graph to the right by units and down by units, and the equation would be: y = 11(x - ) -

statement.p:
The equation of a line with slope m, passing through the origin, is just:
y = mx
If we wanted to change this line so it had the same slope but passed through the point (a,b), what would be the equation?
This is a very useful formula for writing the equation of a line if you know the slope and any single point on its graph. This formula is called the Point-Slope formula for a line.

solution.p:
The equation is
y = m(x-a) + b
no matter the sign (+ or -) on the values a and b.
